Box 127788 Abu Dhabi UAE Graphical abstract Metal substitution in aluminophosphates is known to induce unique structural and surface characteristics that can tune catalytic performance. Si, Co, Fe and Mg substituted AlPO4-5 (MeAPO-5) catalysts were hydrothermally prepared, characterized, and evaluated for ethanol - acetic acid esterification. Textural evaluation revealed that the Co and Si analogues possessed an order of magnitude higher mesopore volume compared to the rest of the studied materials. Divalent metal ions (i.e. Co, Fe, and Mg) substituted preferentially Al ions via the SM1 mechanism, as confirmed by the P/Al being greater than one, while Si ions substituted P ions (SM2) initially, followed by substitution of pairs of Al-P ions (SM3) at higher Si content. The esterification catalytic activity was found to follow the order SAPO-5 > > CoAPO-5 > MgAPO-5 ≈ FeAPO-5. The superior performance of SAPO-5 is ascribed to the higher concentration of Brønsted acid sites and faster mass transfer rates due to the relatively small crystal size and larger fraction of mesopores. Notably, the SAPO-5 with the optimal Si content demonstrated comparable stability against deactivation within the range of reaction conditions studied and sustained catalytic activity at prolonged reaction durations when compared to commercial Zeolite β, despite the significantly higher surface area, pore volume and density of acid sites of the latter, primarily attributed to less strong adsorption of the reaction products. The reported parametric results for various metal substitutions shed light towards optimizing aluminophosphate catalysts for esterification applications. Keywords Esterification Aluminophosphates Ethanol Acetic acid Conversion Ester Solid acid catalysts SAPO-5 Acidity 1 Introduction Organic esters are essential chemicals that have applications in numerous fields such as plasticizers, solvents, pharmaceuticals and intermediates[1] [4][]. Generally, organic esters are commercially produced by reactions occurring between organic alcohols and carboxylic acids in the presence of liquid acid catalysts such as hydrochloric acid or sulfuric acid. In spite of the effective performance of homogenous acid catalysts, the latter have been accompanied with several challenges such as occurrence of side reactions and difficulty in catalyst separation from the product mixture [4] []. Therefore, heterogeneous catalysts such as microporous solids (e.g. zeolites), metal oxides, carbon/graphitic structures, and clays have attracted particular attention for esters production [1][3][2]. Zeolites like zeolite-Y, MOR, BEA and ZSM-5 have been proven to be efficient contenders for the esterification reaction [3–10]. For instance, Bedard et al. [11] reported the catalytic assessment of series of protonated forms of BEA, FER, MFI, and MOR zeolites for ethanol esterification with acetic acid. A catalytic performance with an ethyl acetate selectivity greater than 90 % was recorded over all four zeolites. Wu et al. [12] investigated the catalytic activity of ZSM-5 for acetic acid esterification with ethanol, which showed high yield of ethyl acetate (85 %) at 110 °C for an equimolar feed. In lieu to zeolites, microporous aluminophosphates (AlPOs) have attracted great interest in the field of catalysis, adsorption, as well as in applications such as non-linear optics [13–16]. The considerable interest in AlPO4-n can be ascribed to the structural versatility especially upon incorporation of different metals via isomorphic substitution of the aluminum and/or phosphorus ions [17,18]. Introduction of metals into the aluminophosphate framework was first reported in 1986 by Flanigen et al. [19]. Since then, several metals such as Mg, Fe, Mn, Co, Si, Co and Cr have been incorporated to enhance the acidity and redox properties of AlPO4-n [13,20–24]. Among the AlPO4-n family, AlPO4-5 is a well-known aluminophosphate exhibiting AFI topology, which is characterized by the existence of one-dimensional parallel channels extending across the out-of-plane axis [13,25]. Metal substituted aluminophosphates (MeAPO-5) have demonstrated enhanced catalytic performance in various reactions such as benzene alkylation [26], selective oxidation of glycerol [27], dehydrogenation of ethane [28] and phenol hydroxylation [29]. In the field of esterification, limited studies have been reported on the use of AlPOs as catalysts. For instance, Abd El-Wahab et al. [30] investigated AlPO4-V2O5 catalysts with various vanadia loadings (1–30 mol %) for gas phase esterification of ethanol with acetic acid at a temperature of 210 °C. They reported that AlPO4-V2O5 (30 %) catalyst exhibited 65 % ethanol conversion and nearly 85 % selectivity towards ethyl acetate, which was attributed to the increased number of acid sites due to the addition of V2O5. Said et al. [31] synthesized a series of MoO3/AlPO4 catalysts (5–50 mol%) for vapor phase esterification reaction of acetic acid with ethanol. The maximum yield of ethyl acetate, approximately 45 %, was obtained over a 10 % MoO3/AlPO4 catalyst at 210 °C and ambient pressure. The improved performance was correlated to the creation of stronger acid sites upon the addition of MoO3. The aforementioned studies highlight the importance of the nature of incorporated metal/metal oxide on the esterification reaction performance. Yet, a systematic and parametric study on the impact of metal incorporation in AlPO4-5 on the esterification performance is needed. Herein, we assess the esterification catalytic activity of a series of metal substituted AlPO4-5 using Si, Co, Fe, and Mg as the substituting ions. The selection of the particular metals is anticipated to bring enhancement in ethanol conversion mainly by: i) affecting the resulting morphology and textural characteristics of the catalysts thus leading to higher mass transfer rates and ii) increasing the concentration and strength of the created acids sites. The conducted catalytic experiments were supplemented by various characterization analyses including X-ray Diffraction (XRD), liquid N2 adsorption, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) imaging, EDAX elemental analysis, and NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD). 2 Experimental Section 2.1 Catalyst synthesis The metal substituted AlPO4-5 catalysts were prepared hydrothermally using a gel solution with a molar composition: Al2O3: 1.3 P2O5: x Me: 1.2 TEA: 100 H2O (x = 0.025−0.2), where Me is a divalent, trivalent or tetravalent ion, and TEA is the organic template (trimethylamine). Samples possessing higher Si content were also synthesized (x = 0.05−0.8). The precursors for phosphorus and alumina were phosphoric acid (H3PO4 85 wt %, Aldrich) and aluminum isopropoxide (98 wt %, Aldrich), respectively, while TEA (99 wt %, Aldrich) was used as structure directing agent (SDA). The metal ions were provided from the following sources: cobalt (II) acetate tetrahydrate (99.99 wt %, Aldrich), iron (III) nitrate nonahydrate (≥ 99.99 wt %, Aldrich), tetraethyl orthosilicate (≥ 99 wt %, Aldrich) and magnesium chloride anhydrous (≥ 98 wt %, Aldrich). For comparison purposes, commercial zeolite β (100 wt %, Zeolyst CP814E, Si/Al = 25) was used for benchmarking the obtained catalytic activity. Initially, alumina precursor (5.88 g) was placed in a high-density polyethylene bottle containing distilled water (25.28 g), followed by stirring for 3 h. Phosphoric acid (4.31 g) was then introduced under stirring, followed by dropwise addition of the TEA template (1.75 g). The desired metal precursor was dissolved in water and then introduced to the solution. The resulting gel was stirred for 24 h and the final pH of the gel was in the range of 5−6. The resulting solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was placed into an oven for 24 h at a temperature of 150 °C. The resulting product was recovered and washed six times with water and then centrifuged. Subsequently, the product was dried for 3 h at 100 °C. Finally, the powder was calcined at 600 °C for 6 h using a ramp rate 10 °C/min under flowing air stream using a horizontal tube furnace to remove the occluded organic template and activate porosity. The following samples were prepared by varying the metal type and content: MgAPO-5 (0.2), FeAPO-5 (0.2), CoAPO-5(0.05), SAPO-5(0.05), SAPO-5(0.2), and SAPO-5(0.8), with the number in parenthesis indicating the metal molar composition in the initial synthesis gel. 2.2 Catalyst characterization XRD analysis was conducted using a Panalytical X’Pert PRO Powder Diffractometer. Approximately 30 mg was firstly dried at 100 °C overnight followed by XRD analysis using Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 A˚, 40 kV, 40 mA). The diffraction patterns were collected through a 2θ range of 3° - 50° with a step size of 0.02° and a dwell time of 100 s. The SEM instrument utilized to study the morphology of the samples was a FEI Quanta 250 FEG. The electron source was a Schottky field emission gun with spatial resolution of approximately 1 nm at 30 kV and 3 nm at 1 kV (SE). Elemental analysis and phase mapping were conducted using an Apollo silicon drift detector (SDD) integrated with the EDAX Genesis software. Crystal/particle size determination was performed by measurement of the dominating length of more than 30 crystals/particles. The height for the columnar crystals was considered as the dominant length. The diameter/diagonal length was considered the dominant length in cubic and spherical particles/crystals. N2 adsorption-desorption analysis was carried out at 77 K by using a Micromeritics 3-Flex analyzer. 0.2−0.3 g of catalyst was used for each analysis and the samples were outgassed at 350 °C at a pressure of 10−6 Torr for 6 h before adsorption measurements. Surface areas were determined using the BET method. The total pore volume was determined from nitrogen adsorption data based on the volume adsorbed at a relative pressure of approximately 0.99 to 1. The pore size distribution and pore volume were determined by applying BJH and Horvath-Kawazoe (HK) models using the micro active software™. Temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) was performed using an Autochem 2920 (Micromeritics, Atlanta, USA) to evaluate the acidity of the catalysts. Initially, 60 mg of the catalyst was pretreated at 300 °C for 1 h in helium gas. Then the temperature was decreased to 30 °C before passing a gas mixture of 2 % NH3 in helium for 1 h at a 30 cm3/min flow rate. Flushing with helium for another 1 h was followed to remove any physisorbed NH3. The NH3 desorption was recorded continuously using a TCD detector while increasing the temperature to 700 °C at 10 °C/min under helium. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation The esterification experiments were conducted in a 50 mL three-necked flask, operating in a batch mode. Ethanol, acetic acid and MeAPO-5 catalysts were charged into the reactor and stirred continuously using a magnetic stirrer. Then, the system was heated up to the target temperature. All experiments were conducted at constant volume of the reaction mixture (24 mL) and a molar ratio of acetic acid to ethanol of 20:1 (hereafter denoted as M). The catalytic tests were conducted at two reaction temperatures, i.e. 45 °C and 75 °C and the reaction was carried out for 3 h. Samples were collected periodically and were analyzed by an Agilent HP 7890 Gas Chromatographer (GC) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a DB-WAXETR column (L =30 m, ID =0.32 mm). For comparison, the reaction was also conducted without the addition of any catalyst (hereafter denoted as the blank sample). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts structural and morphological characteristics XRD patterns of the metal substituted AlPO4-5 are shown in Fig. 1 (a). Commercial zeolite beta was also examined, which exhibited all the characteristic Bragg reflections of the BEA-type structure. The main diffraction peaks in the for MeAPO-5 materials observed at ∼20°, 22°, and 23° (2θ) correspond to the (210) (002) and (211) crystallographic planes of the AlPO4-5 AFI structure, respectively [32]. Qualitatively, the AFI structure of AlPO4-5 was preserved in all MeAPO-5 materials even at the highest metal incorporation level of 0.2, except for cobalt wherein the structure collapsed at incorporation levels above 0.05. Yet, isomporphic substitution of metals is expected to cause structural modifications, reflected by contraction or expansion of the unit cell parameters [33]. The unit cell parameters of MeAPO-5 samples were computed and the results are listed in Table 1 . The d-spacing between the lattice planes and the 2θ angles of the peaks, 7.5° (100) and 21° (002), was determined using Full Prof Suite Toolbar. The calculation procedure of the lattice parameters is reported in our previous work [32]. In comparsion to the parent AlPO4-5 (a=13.74 Å, c=8.38 Å), considerable increase of lattice parameter c with Fe incorporation proves the successful substitution of the metal into the framework. This finding is ascribed to the larger ionic radii of Fe3+ (0.65 Å) when compared to Al3+ (0.53 Å) or P5+ (0.34 Å) [20,34,35]. On the other hand, a slight decrease of lattice paramters a and c was recorded with Co2+ incorporation. It has been reported that, at low Co loading, a fraction of the divalent Co2+ ions are oxidized to a trivalent state (Co3+) during calcination [18]. This contraction in unit cell can be explained by the weaker electrostatic repulsive forces present between Co3+ and bonded oxygen atoms which allow for tight packing between atoms [18]. Considering Si incorporation, the XRD patterns at various loadings indicate the stability of the framework even for higher Si contents (Fig. 2 ). All SAPO-5 samples exhibited a slight deviation of unit cell parameter a with the exception of SAPO-5(0.8) wherein a significant decrease was obtained. The latter is in accordance with the prevailing SM3 mechanism at higher Si conent, in which the Al3+ ions, having larger ionic radii than Si4+ (0.42 Å [34]), are replaced by Si ions. This finding is in line with previous reports [34,36]. SEM micrographs of the studied samples are shown in Fig. 1(b–e). The H2O/Al2O3 molar ratio of 100 is known to promote formation of particles comprised of intergrown crystals displaying preferential growth along the in-plane axis (low aspect ratio) [15,37,38]. With the exception of CoAPO-5(0.05) and SAPO-5(0.05), all the samples consist of intergrown crystals displaying preferential growth along the in-plane axis mixed with single crystals displaying preferential growth along the out-of-plane axis. The average agglomerate particle size increases in the following order: Co < Si < Fe < Mg, while the crystal sizes increase approximately following the order: Si < Co < Mg. The observed morphologies are inline with several reported works [37,39,40]. The average particle size for the silicon-substituted catalysts increases with silicon content (Fig. 2). The commercial Beta zeolite exhibited a sponge-like structure comprised of irregular and ragged particles as per the SEM images collected (Figure S1). The isomorphic substitution by which the metal is incorporated into the aluminophosphate framework can occur by three different mechanisms: (1) substitution of Al sites (SM1); (2) substitution of P sites (SM2); and (3) substitution of adjacent pair of P and Al atoms (SM3). The first mechanism (SM1) usually takes place when mono, di and tri-valent metal ions are incorporated into AlPO4-n, thus forming MO P bond. However, substitution by tetra- and penta-valent metal ion is complex, and may follow one or a combination of the aforementioned mechanisms [41–43]. The change in P/Al ratio of the metal-substituted AlPOs is in comparison to unity (1) for pure AlPO4-5. AlPO4-5 has a neutral framework that is based on alternation of AlO4 and PO4 tetrahedra, indicating that P/Al ratio is always unity. Scheme 1 illustrates the three substitution mechanisms. EDAX compositional analysis of the aforementioned samples is shown in Table 1. Due to their divalent state, Co, Fe, and Mg preferentially replace Al ions in the framework, as evidenced by the P/Al ratio is greater than one for all the aforementioned metal substituted samples [44]. Silicon incorporation however is known to prefer phosphorus ions substitution (SM2 mechanism) initially followed by substitution of pairs of Al-P ions (SM3) [45]. Apparently, the aforementioned substitution mode (i.e. substitution of pairs of Al-P ions) is preferred as evidenced by the Al/P ∼ 1 on the SAPO-5 samples. 3.2 Catalysts textural properties The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the MeAPO-5 materials are depicted in Fig. 3 a. Moreover, the textural properties estimated from BET analysis and the HK method are presented in Table 2 . Fig. 3a reveals that all samples exhibit a high nitrogen uptake at low relative pressures (P/Po) confirming their microporous structure. Apart from MgAPO-5, the rest of the catalysts exhibit a hysteresis loop extending at P/Po from 0.45 to 1, which confirms the existence of mesopores, in accordance to type- IV isotherm, as per IUPAC classification. A steep increase in the slope at high relative pressure range (P/Po > 0.8) in CoAPO-5 is attributed to capillary condensation, evidencing an extended mesoporous network in this catalyst. The existence of mesopores and their associated pore size distribution is shown in the inset of Fig. 3. The SAPO-5 material exhibits its main peak of narrow mesopore size distribution centered at 3.5 nm. CoAPO-5 on the other hand, exhibits a wide mesopore size distribution. MgAPO-5 does not show a hysteresis loop and exhibits Type-I isotherm thus indicating the absence of mesoporosity. An artifact of slightly decreasing adsorbed amount with increasing pressure starting at P/P0 of 0.4 needs to be noted in MgAPO-5 and FeAPO-5 samples, which is attributed to a minor amount of He from the free space determination procedure remaining entrained within the micropores. Still, the effect is minimal and does not affect the determination of the related textural properties. HK micropore size distribution of all the samples (Fig. 3b) reveals an average pore size of ∼0.7 nm which coincides with the main channel width in AlPO4-5 AFI structure. From Table 2, the BET surface area of the MeAPO-5 catalysts varies from 250 to 370 m2/g, the pore volume from 0.1 to 0.14 cc/g, and average pore diameter from ∼1.5 to 2.0 nm. The largest value of mesopore volume for the CoAPO-5 and SAPO-5 samples and the respective negligible mesopore volume for MgAPO-5 are in accordance with previously reported porosity studies [46]. Compared to MeAPO-5 materials, commercial Zeolite beta presented the highest surface area (545.4 m2/g), pore volume (0.73 cc/g), and average mesopore size (5.36 nm), a fact that is also ascribed to the inter-particle spacing [47]. The low microporosity observed in the FeAPO-5(0.2) and CoAPO-5(0.05) could be partially attributed to the presence of a minor non-porous amorphous phase or to incomplete removal of the template. It should also be noted that Fe incorporation is particularly sensitive to metal clustering and existence of extra-framework metal species particularly at increased metal content, as has been shown before by spectroscopy studies [48,49]. In this case, dropping in pore volume due to the existence of such clusters is possible. Furthermore, the ionic radius of substituting Fe is larger than that of Al thus possibly causing drop of the pore volume inside the microporous channels. 3.3 Catalyst surface acidity assessment via NH3-TPD The evaluation of the surface acidity was perfomed by thermal desorption of ammonia (TPD-NH3). The formation of Brønsted acidity is shown in Scheme 2 . The transition metal incoprporation (TMI) introduces Brønsted acidity to the catalyst as shown in the scheme. The concentration of acid sites as obtained by NH3-TPD and the associated results are tabulated in Table 3 . In order to critically assess the acid sites population on the studied catalysts the following points are useful: (a) thermal calcination affects the oxidation state of Co (Co2+ to Co3+), and this can alter the symmetry around the Co ions, (b) the oxidation state of Co, Fe has not been determined in this study, yet Fe for instance can also exist as Fe2+, Fe3+ upon the calcination treatment. Based on the results of Table 3, MgAPO-5 presented the lowest concentration of acid sites as compared to all other samples tested. Notably, it possessed lower concentration of acid sites than FeAPO-5 despite the fact that it exhibits higher surface area and pore volume. For SAPO-5, there is a decrease in amount of acid sites upon increasing the Si content from 0.05 to 0.2 (Si/Al). This observation can be explained by the fact that Si atoms substitute only for P atoms (mechanism SM2) at low Si loading, while at high Si content (Si/Al of 0.2), two Si atoms substitute for a pair Al + P (mechanism SM3) in combination with the SM2 mechanism. This combined SM2 + SM3 mechanism has been reported to be responsible for generating less acid sites than SM2 [43,50,51]. The observed increase in acid sites concentration from SAPO-5(0.2) to SAPO-5(0.8) might be attributed to the creation of additional sites by the displaced Al ions, higher crystallinity of the latter sample, and dominance of the SM2 substitution mechanism at higher substitution levels [52]. 4 Catalytic performance evaluation 4.1 Effect of metal substitution It is well established that the concentration and strength of Brønsted acid sites play a key role in catalytic esterification reactions [9,53]. Koo et.al [53] studied the esterification of acetic acid with methanol over palladium-promoted H-ferrierite and H-ZSM5 catalysts. The results revealed that the improved acivity of H-ZSM5, compared to that of H-Ferrierite, was attributed to the higher concentration of Brønsted acid sites on the former, even though the total acid sites concentration was higher on H-Ferrierite. Following modification with Pd, both catlysts, Pd/H-Ferrierite and Pd/H-ZSM5, exhibited a considerable enhancement in activity and methyle acetate selectivity, ascribed to the suppression of the strong Brønsted acid sites present. Fig. 4 depicts the conversion evolution corresponding to the various catalysts as a function of time at 75 °C using a fixed catalyst loading of 1.5 g in the reaction mixture. The order of ethanol conversion over the used catalysts is as follows: SAPO-5<< CoAPO-5 < MgAPO-5 ≈ FeAPO-5 ≈ blank sample. The higher performance of SAPO-5 over CoAPO-5 can be attributed to the higher concentration of Brønsted acid sites upon Si substitution [53,54]. Furthermore, the relatively smaller particle sizes and existence of mesoporosity enhance mass transfer rates. Notably, the above factors enhance the catalytic performance of the CoAPO-5 catalyst over MgAPO-5 and FeAPO-5 despite the significantly lower metal content of the former. In addition to the relatively low content of acid sites, mass transfer limitations induced by the larger crystal size of MgAPO and FeAPO and absence of mesoporosity may be responsible to a large extent for the observed hinderance for these materials to catalyze the reaction thus the latter progressing predominantly in the bulk liquid (lack of enhancement compared to the self-catalyzed activity). 4.2 Effect of silicon content and reaction temperature The acetic acid esterification is an acid-catalyzed reaction, thereby the Si/Al ratio is an essential parameter affecting the catalytic performance of the involved microporous catalysts. From the aforementioned results, SAPO-5(0.2) exhibits the highest ethanol conversion compared to the rest of tested catalysts. To elucidate the Si loading effect on the activity of SAPO-5, three catalysts with various Si concentrations, x = 0.05, 0.2 and 0.8, were investigated at a fixed temperature of 75 °C, M = 20, and fixed catalyst loading of 1.5 g. A pronounced improvement in conversion was observed with increasing Si concentration as depicted in Fig. 5 a. It is noteworthy that the nature of Si incorporation into AlPO4-5 and its impact on hydrophobicity are greatly affected by Si/Al ratio [55]. The effect is not anticipated to be similar to that for aluminosilicate zeolites given that the latter are intrinsically hydrophilic, whereas AlPO4-5 exhibits a rather hydrophobic character, as shown in our previous work [25]. Furthermore, Gómez-Hortigüela et al. [55] reported that the predominance of the SM2 mechanism imparts a more hydrophilic character to the SAPO-5 structure, owing to the generation of Brønsted acid sites, whereas incorporation of Si via the combined SM2 + SM3 mechanism results in more hydrophobic structure. Therefore, the relatively inferior activity of SAPO-5(0.05) could be attributed to its hydrophilic character, due to Si substitution via the SM2 mechanism, as confirmed by TPD results, giving rise to a facile adsorption of water, thereby poisoning acid sites [9]. In addition, the effects related to sites strength as well as particle size, degree of crystal agglomeration into the catalyst particles, and crystallinity are also anticipated to affect conversion. Conversely, the deactivation of active sites induced by adsorption of water was suppressed over SAPO-5(0.8) owing to its enhanced hydrophobic nature, which was obtained as a result of Si substitution via the combined SM2 + SM3 mechanism, as revealed by TPD analysis. In order to explore the temperature effect on the SAPO-5 – catalyzed esterification reaction, experiments were conducted over the SAPO-5(0.8) catalyst at 45 °C and 75 °C (fixed catalyst loading of 1.5 g and M = 20). Fig. 5b reveals that the ethanol conversion strongly depends on the reaction temperature, as increasing the temperature from 45 to 75 °C resulted in an almost five-fold increase in conversion after 3 h time on stream. Hence, in SAPO-5 the observed reaction rates are dominantly controlled by chemical kinetics rather than by mass transfer, which is in agreement to observations reported by Mallaiah et al. on other similarly sized microporous materials [56]. Bedard et al. [11] studied the kinetics of gas phase esterification of ethanol with acetic acid on a series of protonated forms of BEA, FER, MFI, and MOR zeolites at ethanol and acetic acid partial pressure range of 5–13 kPa and 0.5–6 kPa respectively. Results indicated that the reaction is kinetically limited and the activation energy was estimated to be within the range of 45−70 kJ/mol. Based on the two temperatures tested in our results, the activation energy was found to be 74 kJ/mol which is higher than that reported by Bedard et al. [11]. It should be noted however that Bedard et al., conducted the experiments in gas phase, while we have conducted our experiments in liquid phase. This finding supports the claim that the reaction over SAPO-5(0.8) catalyst is not mass transfer limited. 4.3 Comparison with commercial Zeolite β (BEA) Commercial zeolites have been extensively employed to catalyze esterification reactions. The catalytic performance of commercial Zeolite β was compared herein to the prepared SAPO-5 (0.2) catalyst under the same reaction conditions (75 °C, catalyst loading of 1 g). According to Fig. 6 , both catalysts display a similar catalytic activity up to 80 min from the onset of reaction, which suggests similarity in the acidic strength of the sites. For prolonged reaction time (longer than 140 min), the SAPO-5 (0.2) catalyst exhibited an improved conversion compared to Zeolite β catalyst. Indeed, the conversion for the former catalyst continued to increase for prolonged times on stream, whereas the commercial zeolite β reached an upper limit of conversion at 55 %, which did not increase any further with time. The fact that further increase in reaction time did not show a significant increase in conversion for zeolite β can be ascribed to faster BEA deactivation as a result of strong adsorption of products, which leads to blocking of active sites and reduced accessibility of fresh reactants to active sites, thus reducing catalytic activity [57]. In practical application, this implies that at this point the process needs to be terminated and the catalyst needs to be regenerated and/or replaced, resulting in cost increase and productivity loss. Compared to Zeolite β, SAPO-5 (0.2) preserved its ability to continue converting ethanol, hence conversion kept increasing linearly with time even at extended duration. Notably, zeolite β exhibits significantly higher surface area, pore volume and density of acid sites of the latter compared to the SAPO-5 used. The SAPO-5 (0.2) catalyst therefore was found to demonstrate high stability against deactivation and prolonged performance. 4.4 Reaction kinetics The power law model was employed to represent the catalyzed esterification reaction using the MeAPO-5 (Me = Co, Mg, Fe and Si) catalysts as well as the non-catalyzed reaction. The rate of esterification reaction is assumed to be first order in ethanol [7,58]. The overall reaction equation is: (1) Notably, the esterification reaction exhibits a strong non-ideal behavior owing to the presence of ethanol and water, which are highly polar molecules compared to non-polar ethyl acetate [59]. To this extend, the non-ideal behavior of the liquid mixture was taken into account by adopting activity coefficients in lieu of concentration in the reaction rate expression. Considering the reaction given by equation (1), the reaction rate of ethanol in a constant volume isothermal system, neglecting the backward reaction for a large excess of one reactant (i.e. acetic acid) [60] [61], is expressed as follows: (2) - r A = d C A d t = ( k c a t w + k h o m o ) C A γ A Where: C A a n d C B are ethanol and acetic acid concentrations respectively, w is the catalyst loading, and γ A is the activity coefficients, kcat and khomo are the catalyzed and homogeneous reaction rate constant, respectively. Equation (2) can be written in terms of ethanol conversion X A as below: (3) - r A = - C A 0 d X A d t = ( k c a t w + k h o m o ) C A 0 ( 1 - X A ) γ A Rearranging Equation (3) and integrating we obtain: (4) ∫ 0 X A d X A ( 1 - X A ) = ( k c a t w + k h o m o ) γ A ∫ 0 t d t The change in γ A values is negligible, thus they were considered constants. Integration of Equation] (4) leads to: (5) - ln 1 - X A = k c a t w + k h o m o γ A t By plotting - ln 1 - X A versus time, a straight line was obtained, displaying a high correlation coefficients ( R 2 ) as shown in Fig. 7 (75 °C, catalyst loading 1.5 g). This clearly reveals that the proposed kinetic model is appropriate for the studied system. The assumption of constant activity coefficient (γ ) was also verified. The UNIFAC program was adopted to calculate the activity coefficient of ethanol, which in general is functions of temperature and mole fraction. These values are listed in Table S1. Apparently, the change in the activity coefficients is small during the reaction, therefore the activity coefficient was considered as constant and the average values were used in determining the rate constants. The reaction rate constants for different MeAPO-5 catalysts obtained from the slopes of the - ln 1 - X A versus time plots are tabulated in Table 4 . Evidently, the catalyzed reaction rate constant (k cat) was found to be the highest for the SAPO-5 catalyst followed by CoAPO-5, which is in agreement to the obtained experimental results. On the other hand, both FeAPO-5 (0.2) and MgAPO-5 (0.2) exhibited no catalytic activity for this reaction. Table 4 shows also the reaction rate per acid site for MeAPO-5 materials. As expected, SAPO-5 (0.2) presented higher reaction rate per acid site compared to CoAPO-5 (0.05), which is attributed to higher Brønsted acidity of the former [54]. This observation supports the aforementioned claim that esterification reaction is contingent on the type of acid sites, particulary Brønsted acid sites, rather than the total number of acid sites. The latter is in accordacne with the results reported by Koo et.al [53]. 5 Conclusions In this work, we have demonstrated the impact of metal ion substitution of auminophosphate catalysts on esterification using MeAPO-5 catalysts and acetic acid esterification as the probe reaction. Incorporation of Si and Co into the AlPO4-5 framework led to the formation of relatively small particles comprised of aggregated crystals displaying preferential growth along the in-plane directions, while evidence of large mesopore volume emerged into those samples. On the contrary, Mg- and Fe- incorporated samples led to the formation of relatively large crystals with limited mesoporosity. The aforementioned morphological and textural differences manifested on the catalytic activity of the studied samples. Si-substituted AlPO4-5 exhibited superior catalytic activity compared to all other calatysts tested. The enhanced catalytic activity of SAPO-5 is attributed to the presence of higher concentration of Brønsted acid sties exhibiting high reaction rates per acid site, smaller particle size, and higher mesopority which allow for faster mass transfer rates. The catalytic activity was found to follow the order: SAPO-5 > > CoAPO-5 > MgAPO-5 ≈ FeAPO-5 ≈ blank. Comparative studies with commercial Zeolite β under the same reaction conditions revealed that SAPO-5 displayed high stability against deactivation and sustained performance at prolonged time on stream within the range of reaction conditions examined. The high sustained performance and high conversion efficiancy, combined with relatively fast reaction rates render SAPO-5 a promising contender in catalyzing esterification reactions. coredata.dc:description: Metal substitution in aluminophosphates is known to induce unique structural and surface characteristics that can tune catalytic performance. Si, Co, Fe and Mg substituted AlPO4-5 (MeAPO-5) catalysts were hydrothermally prepared, characterized, and evaluated for ethanol - acetic acid esterification. Textural evaluation revealed that the Co and Si analogues possessed an order of magnitude higher mesopore volume compared to the rest of the studied materials. Divalent metal ions (i.e. Co, Fe, and Mg) substituted preferentially Al ions via the SM1 mechanism, as confirmed by the P/Al being greater than one, while Si ions substituted P ions (SM2) initially, followed by substitution of pairs of Al-P ions (SM3) at higher Si content. The esterification catalytic activity was found to follow the order SAPO-5 > > CoAPO-5 > MgAPO-5 ≈ FeAPO-5. The superior performance of SAPO-5 is ascribed to the higher concentration of Brønsted acid sites and faster mass transfer rates due to the relatively small crystal size and larger fraction of mesopores. Notably, the SAPO-5 with the optimal Si content demonstrated comparable stability against deactivation within the range of reaction conditions studied and sustained catalytic activity at prolonged reaction durations when compared to commercial Zeolite β, despite the significantly higher surface area, pore volume and density of acid sites of the latter, primarily attributed to less strong adsorption of the reaction products. The reported parametric results for various metal substitutions shed light towards optimizing aluminophosphate catalysts for esterification applications.
coredata.dc:title: Metal substitution effects of aluminophosphate AlPO4-5 as solid acid catalyst for esterification of acetic acid with ethanol
